chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the two items that are not in operating cash flow and why it is excluded in the operating cash flow.

The two items that are excluded in operating cash flow are 

1. **Depreciation Expense** has no outgoing cash flow. It is a non-cash component of operating expense that represents fixed asset book value adjustments made following the matching principle.

2. **Interest Expense** is not an operating cost but a financing cost.
This exercise requires us to identify two items included in net income computation but not operating cash flows. We will also define each of them and discuss the reason for their exclusion.

The difference in the computation of accounting net income and operating cash flows lies in the **timing of recognition**. Entities recognize cash flows when actual cash is received or paid. On the other hand, businesses record income and expenses upon product delivery or service rendition - regardless of cash movements.

Items that typically appear in net income computation, but are not considered in operating cash flows, are:

1. Depreciation.
2. Interest.

### 1. Depreciation.

The **matching principle** states that entities should allocate the cost of long-term assets to the periods used and from which they benefit, regardless of when cash is paid. Although it is classified as an expense in the income statement, the fact that it is a non-cash item indicated that no cash outflow relates to its incurrence, excluding it in operating cash flows computation.

### 2. Interest.

Interest pertains to the costs related to an entity's borrowing transactions. Compared to accounting, finance excludes interest expense incurred in operating cash flows and classifies it as a **financing expense**.

The computation of operating cash flows refers to the excess of revenues after deducting all expenses, except interest and depreciation. It excludes the former because it is a non-cash item while the latter is a financing expense - not an operating cost.
